Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Proximate Mechanisms of Aggression in Role Reversed Species
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hybridization, the breeding of two separate and distinct species, has the potential to merge two species into one when hybrids are fairly healthy, or keep the species separate when hybrids fare poorly. In western Panama, where the species ranges of the tropical shorebirds known as Northern Jacanas and Wattled Jacanas meet, they form a hybrid zone. Jacanas exhibit mating role reversal where females control access to mates by competing for territories encompassing a harem of males, and males provide all parental care. The unusual circumstance of hybridization between species with such a unique mating system offers a window into examining why and how species-specific boundaries to mating fail, from a female perspective. Genetic and experimental evidence suggests that differences in aggressive behavior between the species may explain patterns of hybridization. Females of the more aggressive species produce the majority of hybrid offspring. The proposed research employs techniques to assess the expression of genes to examine variation in aggressive behavior between the hybridizing species. This research addresses a fundamental question in ecology, evolution, and behavior what is the genetic basis of behavioral differences? This can 1) improve our understanding of the behavioral mechanisms important in species formation, and 2) provide insight into the genetic mechanisms underlying behavioral differences between males and females. Understanding of science and research will be communicated through workshops with local school aged children and ecotourists at the Panamanian field site.

Between recently diverged species, mating behavior can either impede or promote reproductive isolation. Theoretical and empirical evidence demonstrates this for female mate choice and male competition, but little is known about the relative roles of each. Female aggression has only recently been recognized as an adaptive behavior, and how its underlying mechanisms compare to those of males is not well understood. A key step towards understanding the evolutionary significance of the competitive phenotype in females is determining its underlying genomic mechanisms. The goal of the proposed research is to elucidate the molecular basis of the female competitive phenotype by identifying clusters of candidate genes whose differential expression is responsible for consistent variation in aggressive behavior. This study combines aggression assays with a transcriptomic approach to address this question in role reversed, hybridizing Northern Jacanas (Jacana spinosa)and Wattled Jacanas (J. jacana) in Central America. This project is novel with respect to understanding the mechanisms by which phenotypes change as role reversed species diverge, which could advance our understanding of how organisms respond and adapt to changing environmental selection. By identifying how the genes underlying aggression are differentially expressed between role reversed females and males, the proposed research will expand upon general principles in sexual selection theory that have been developed in well-known male-dominant systems. Furthermore, this project investigates the genetic underpinnings of complex behavioral traits in wild, free-living, non-model organisms, which is vital for understanding the evolution of ecologically relevant phenotypes under natural conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 1975, evolutionary biologist GC Williams asked "Why are males masculine, females feminine and occasionally vice-versa?" Those vice-versa's inspire research on animal systems that are ?role-reversed,? because they challenge our assumptions about male and female roles in the wild. A classic example are role reversed jacanas, which are tropical shorebirds. Female jacanas have higher expression of competitive traits than males, including larger body mass and longer weaponry ? they have sharp wing spurs. Females compete intensely over breeding territories and mate with multiple males on their territory. In contrast, males conduct all parental care, including incubating eggs and foraging with chicks.

How does role-reversal arise? One hormonal hypothesis is that role-reversed females have higher testosterone than males, which could facilitate the expression of competitive traits. To test this hypothesis, we examined female and male Northern Jacanas (Jacana spinosa) in Panama during the breeding season, when females competed for territories and males were at two different breeding stages ? either competing to court females, or caring for eggs or chicks. We found that courting males had higher levels of testosterone in circulation that females, but that males conducting parental care had similar levels of testosterone to females (Figure 1). Among other species of birds, testosterone is typically higher in males, and also decreases during periods of parental care, suggesting jacanas do not deviate from this typical pattern.

Next, we hypothesized that competitive behavior and morphology may relate to testosterone sensitivity. To measure competitive behaviors like aggression, we simulated territorial intrusions using a taxidermy mount and speaker ? a low tech bird robot that wild birds attacked (Figure 2). Females with more testosterone had bigger weapons. Males with more testosterone had larger testes, but only during courtship. Testosterone didn't explain variation in aggression. These results coupled with prior research indicate that divergent roles of female mating competition and male parental care may also have divergent physiological regulation between the sexes. Could role-reversal by explained by genes expressed in socially relevant regions of the brain? We are currently testing this hypothesis.

Funding from this project supported doctoral student Sara Lipshutz?s training as a biologist integrating behavioral, hormonal, and bioinformatics techniques. She has won several awards for her PhD research, including the Allee Award for best dissertation at the Animal Behavior Society conference, best student presentation in behavior at the American Ornithological Society, and University of Tennessee's Jim Tanner Award for Outstanding Dissertation. Dr. Lipshutz presented this research at four academic conferences, six departmental seminars, and has published three academic manuscripts on this topic (see recent coverage in The Conversation). During this research project, Dr. Lipshutz trained a master's student and six undergraduate students in field and laboratory techniques, and these students are continuing to pursue research and careers in related STEM fields. Dr. Lipshutz has also shared this research with 100+ K-12 students across the country (TX, CO, NJ, IA, WA) through the program Skype a Scientist. Dr. Lipshutz has also performed an interpretive dance about female competition in jacanas (Figure 3) and presented this research to colleagues and community members at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama. 

The financial and intellectual support Dr. Lipshutz received from this grant was fundamental in driving her research interests towards evolutionary physiology, her current research area as an NSF Postdoctoral Fellow in Biology. Her long-term research goals are to understand female competition at multiple levels of analysis, from the hormonal, genetic, and neural mechanisms underlying its development and expression, to the social functions of female competition, to the evolution of female competition across lineages.
